description:
More prominent Posted signs regarding dogs need to be placed in West Roxbury 's Millennium Park. Dog owners allow their dogs to run free like children in a playground. Many different owners gather and what results is a pack of rambunctious dogs taking over the upper level of the park. Not only is it a safety issue to the small children and adults jogging/walking it is also a health issue as the dogs defecate through out the park and the dog owner looks away. Below is a picture if signs that are in the  Boston Common. These signs should be posted in all the parking lots just before entering into the parks fenced area. Proper patrolling and ticketing would also be helpful. Please do not wait until a tragedy happens. Today I saw a woman pushing a baby stroller have a large dog sprint across a field and go right to the toddler in the stroller knocking the stroller over with force. Had it not been for the Mother if the toddler who sprawled across her child and stroller and kick the dog away, I would hate to think what could have happened.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. This intersection does not meet the criteria for the installation of a crosswalk. Two crosswalks are located in very close proximity to this intersection at West 2nd and West 3rd, only approx. 100 feet away in each direction. According to the MUTCD, crosswalks should not be placed less than 200 feet apart. Additionally, the number of pedestrians that would use a crosswalk here, if installed, does not meet the 15-20 pedestrians per hour minimum.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. The Boston Public Works requires utility companies or private contractors to place florescent reflective signs on poles whenever a steel plate is to be used, or a trench is down low awaiting the final top course. This allows the Public to know before the drive over a plate or a trench in progress, so that they can proceed with caution. It improves safety for both motorists, and the crews. South Boston has a tremendous amount of utility work being done. Most of the work is for new water, sewer, and drain mains. This will dramatically improve the infrastructure of the South Boston neighborhood. When the work is completed, the City will pave the streets, and not have to worry about emergency repairs being made soon after paving. You are correct that the signs should be removed after the work is done. The sign on H St has been removed. I will send out an email to all contractors reminding them that it is mandatory to remove the signs after the work has been completed. The City apologizes for the inconvenience. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. As of 5/17/14, the sign has been removed. The City apologizes for the inconvenience the expired sign caused. Whenever a utility company or private contractor plans on excavating into the roadway or sidewalks, they must call Dig Safe. It is a State law. All of the other utilities near the pipe or conduit that plans to be excavated must be marked out in the interest of public safety. Paint has to be used, and it must be clearly visible. The City understands the frustration of dig safe markings. We are currently asking them to look into using paint that does not take as long to wear off. Bottom line, the paint marks are required, and eventually they will wear off. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. NStar Electric was installing new conduit on Corey St. This is the type of infrastructure upgrade work that the City highly encourages. It will eliminate possible future emergency work. The contractor was performing service cut overs, which required the outbound lane of the roadway to be closed. The only traffic allowed on Corey St was the inbound side. The City absolutely agrees that the detour signage was not to City specifications. In addition, they didn't have adequate detour signage to fully allow the motorist to navigate an alternate route. NStar was contacted. The agree that they should have done a better job, and that going forward, BTD, BFD, and the MBTA will be alerted and proper detour signage will be placed throughout the entire alternate route. The work is now complete. The City apologizes for the inconvenience. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
description: Corey Street in West Roxbury has been "closed" since at least Thursday of last week during the evening rush hour. Prior to this intersection, there is a sign directing bicyclists to the left, with a bike lane on the left side. Following this intersection, there are no bike markings whatsoever, leaving cyclists in the left lane. status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. Ticket was issued on 5-5-14 by Officer Sheehan.
description:
Sidewalk permanently blocked by open chain-link gate at 24 Leroy St. in Dorchester.

The homeowner at this address always leaves the gate from his driveway wide open on weekdays, blocking 90% of the sidewalk.  The homeowner knows about it, but he cannot be bothered. Although he is an able bodied man, he is too lazy to get out of his car and close the gate after himself when he drives to work in the morning.  

It’s a safety issue. This is a busy sidewalk. Women with baby carriages, kids on scooters, and people using walkers have to get off the sidewalk and walk in the middle of the busy street to get around that gate.   I called the City Hot Line to report the issue. I was transferred a few times. The last person I spoke to didn’t seem to take my request seriously.  From the nonchalant tone in her voice, she made it quite clear that she was going to ignore it. 

I don’t have a picture of it, but you may lookup “24 Leroy St. Boston” on Google Maps, as I did to confirm the address.  Go to “Street View” mode, and you’ll understand what I am talking about.   24 Leroy St. is the light blue three decker to the right of the picture. The wide open gate obstructing the sidewalk is there in plain view, and this picture was taken nearly a year ago.

I am forwarding this message to a few people who have expressed similar concerns. We are looking forward to your help for a prompt resolution. 

Thank you for your consideration.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. I had Ambulance 4 investigate Harrison Av/Sullivan way and they found nothing. They talked to the staff of Pine Street Inn to see if they had any input. The PSI staff  will keep an eye out and call us if they find it. A side-note / recommendation.  The close up picture of a needle up against a wall was not real useful. The website/phone app should really have a suggestion to take a picture from a distance with an identifiable landmark visible in the picture. Taking a close up picture of a needle against a wall really does not help very much. I am not sure who would be update the site/app.   The same applies to the other Bio Waste located on Mt Washington St. The Division 1 supervisor investigated this one and he walked up and down the waterfront looking but a needle is so small that without something to narrow down the location...it does not help.  The picture is relatively up close and nothing but a couple rocks and water in the back ground. A note on the website and/or phone app would go a long way in resolving the Bio waste and avoid needlessly having resources (that are already spread pretty thin) being tied up. ...and as I type this...Division 1 found 12 needles in the area of Mt Washington Street along the Harborwalk . I assume these were the needle(s) in question.   However...it still had an EMS Supervisor tied up for ½ an hour out walking up and down the Harborwalk  looking for the needles. Respectfully. Lt. Beers.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. Hi Craig,. Thanks for your email to the City. It has been a long time since I have. seen  you. I hope you are doing great. We definitely are aware of the expansion joint issue. The City does not. have jurisdiction over the joints itself, but I  have had numerous. conversations with the state and they are aware of the issue. With that. said, the City does have the ability to do signage and pavement markings in. the area. Last year we installed signs and pavement markings in response to. the crash. The pavement markings guide the cyclists to the left side of the. road where the joints are safe. The signage alerts the cyclists to the. issue as well. Despite the efforts, we still are having crashes.  We already added more. signage alerting cyclists.  In addition, after more field work I had our. engineers design much more visible and robust pavement markings that will. be almost impossible to miss.  The in-house engineering team is reviewing. now (they know it is urgent) and I hope to get those installed right away. Thanks so much Craig and keep smiling,. Nicole Freedman. Director of Bicycle Programs.
description: Another cyclist down at the expansion joints. Hubway rider this time. I encouraged her to report it, but got the strong impression she won't. When is the city going to take this road hazard seriously. All it takes is the fall to happen when a truck is right behind you, and that will be another cycling death. Vehicles show no respect here, and the signs are useless because by the time you see them you are already in the midst of the hazard. It will be blood on your hands if you don't think about this spot differently. (Luckily, the Hubway rider was ok this time, just a little bit if blood.)
